Award.AwardTitle: LTREB: Emergent Landscape Patterns in Stream Ecosystem Processes Resulting from Groundwater/Surface Water Interactions
Award.AbstractNarration: The overall scientific objective of this study is to understand how groundwater, supplied to rivers via inter-basin transfers (i.e., from outside the immediate watershed), affects how tropical streams function in the long term (>25 yrs). The project is based in lowland Costa Rica, where solute-rich groundwater account for over half of stream discharge in the dry season. This groundwater is naturally-rich in nutrients such as phosphorus (P), with levels higher than those typically found below sewage treatment plants. Prior research has shown that landscape patterns in stream chemistry (resulting from variation in solute-rich groundwater inputs) reflect rates of primary production and decomposition. This project continues to build a long-term (1988-present) data set on stream solute chemistry, which is the only one for lowland primary rainforests of Central America. The investigators are relating long-term trends in stream chemistry to large-scale climatic phenomena: solute-rich groundwater (also rich in bicarbonates) buffer receiving streams against increases in acidity during periods following El Nino-related droughts, while those streams that do not receive solute-rich groundwater experience dramatic increases in acidity. An outgrowth of the project is the development of an environmental outreach program that focuses on water quality and quantity issues in tropical regions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report:  LTREB: Emergent Landscape Patterns in Stream Ecosystem Processes Resulting from Groundwater/ Surface Water Interactions.

This project is showing us how temporal changes in precipitation associated with climate change are altering stream solute chemistry and changing ecosystem processes in a Neotropical watershed in lowland Costa Rica.  Moreover, we have found that interactions between regional ground- and surface- waters within the watershed mediate stream responses to these changes: streams that receive interbasin transfers of regional solute-rich groundwater appear to be well-buffered and resistant to resultant declines in pH, while poorly-buffered streams influenced by local groundwater are vulnerable. 

While acidification in temperate freshwater systems has been extensively studied, our understanding of acidification in tropical streams has been constrained by the lack of long-term data sets.  Analysis of our long-term (25 yrs) data set on stream solute chemistry in Costa Rica (the only one that we are aware of for lowland primary rainforest of Central America) shows that stream pH in poorly-buffered streams naturally declines throughout the wet season and increases during the dry season.  Moreover, this pattern is amplified during episodic climatic phenomena [i.e. El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) events]: prolonged acidification events (up to several months) occur during ENSO events. During the historically large ENSO event in 1998, pH levels dropped below 4.0 in poorly-buffered streams. In our recent paper in Ecosystems (Small et al. 2012), we show that dissolved CO2 accounts for low baseline pH and we hypothesize that an influx of soil-derived CO2 via local groundwater contributes to pH declines. Results show tight coupling between climate, terrestrial, and aquatic ecosystems in the tropics. 

     Our findings strongly suggest that predicted decreases in dry season rainfall for the tropics are likely to lead to an increased magnitude of seasonal acidification.  In an effort to assess how widespread this phenomenon is, we have linked our long-term data sets to those of other tropical projects by organizing international workshops (e.g., Carbon Transport in Tropical Streams Workshop, La Selva Biological Station, Costa Rica 2010) and special sessions at annual meetings of professional societies (e.g., ASLO Meeting, Puerto Rico 2011).  In terms of education, we are building on our strong track record of graduate/undergraduate training through long-term research by developing a new field course: Neotropical River Ecology and Watershed Conservation.  This course is now offered annually through the Organization for Tropical Studies.  It is taught by project PIs and collaborators in Costa Rica and is open to both US and Latin American students.  Finally, our environmental outreach program, Water for Life/Agua para la Vida, focuses on water quality and quantity issues in tropical regions. It includes a bilingual web site (www.rivercenter.uga.edu/ international/wfl/home_english.htm) and development of teaching materials at the high-school level [i.e. a teaching manual and a volunteer stream monitoring program (Adopte una quebrada) that have been widely used by high schools in Costa Rica]. Three environmental outreach posters on water quality and stream conservation have also been developed and distributed to local school children and the general public in Costa Rica.
